resources.string: One of Solutions\nEach line represents a different solution.

OLL stands for Orientation of the Last Layer, a solving method that aims to memorize all 57 patterns after completing a full face and the adjacent two layers. It is often generalized and simplified into a solving sequence of V-shape → middle 3 → cross → corners → full face. However, this method lacks speed, so OLL aims to quickly solve into a full face using the shortest sequence among the 57 patterns.
 While 57 patterns may sound overwhelming, you'll find that many sequences overlap or are the reverse of each other. As you understand more, it won't feel like that many.

 Below is an explanation of the notation and a summary of common sequences.
 Especially, "U", "R", "F" are frequently used, so memorize them at the very least. B, E are rarely seen, so they are not included.
 To indicate a counter-clockwise rotation, we use the symbol "’". Similarly, "2" is used to indicate a 180-degree rotation. For example, "U’" or "R2".
 A bit trickier, we use "w" to indicate turning two layers. Like "Rw".

 When making cube rotations, the notations x, y, and z are sometimes used. 'x' indicates rotating in the direction of R, 'y' in the direction of U, and 'z' in the direction of F. Adding a 'prime' symbol (') reverses the direction. x' appears fairly frequently.

 There may be different schools of thought on which color to set on top, but the author belongs to the green school, so it is set to green.
Clockwise when viewed from above. U\' is counter-clockwise when viewed from above. Flick with the index finger.
Clockwise when viewed from the right. R\' is counter-clockwise when viewed from the right. Turn with the right hand.
Clockwise when viewed from the front. F\' is counter-clockwise when viewed from the front. The author uses the right index finger and thumb.
Turns only the layer between R and L. Same direction as L. M = Rw\' R, M\' = Rw R\'
Clockwise when viewed from the left. L\' is counter-clockwise when viewed from the left. With practice, using L can sometimes be faster.
Clockwise when viewed from below. D\' is counter-clockwise when viewed from below. Appears occasionally.
Turns the middle layer next to F. Same direction as F. S is used occasionally.
